div.p: 1. IV:15. Thursday

Fine cool, clear, almost autumnal day; such as by my experience always comes at Washington City between the 15th. and 20th of this month— I filled a flower Pot 8. with fresh Earth, and sowed in it white strawberries, white currants, and huckleberries. I have repeatedly made the experiment of raising red and white strawberries and currants from the seed to ascertain if they would reproduce each its own kind— I have raised strawberries, and currants, but they have all proved red— The black currant I know, reproduces itself— There is a perseverance of pursuit directed to the same object in all experiments to raise plants, in which I am lamentably deficient and from which I suffer continual disappointment— I have never succeeded in raising huckleberries from the seed— They grow wild upon low bushes among the rocks, but are never cultivated in gardens—and the attempt to raise them is Shandean— I finished my Letter to Gerrit Smith and that was the labour of the day— A man by the name of Pierce brought me a catchpenny work called Bradford’s Atlas of the United which I had already refused to take last Winter at Washington— I now examined, and again declined to take it— Lewis Bass, last year Chairman of the Selectmen—this year collector of taxes, came for payment of my parish tax which for this year is 210 dollars and which I paid.— The town and county tax 4 I referred for future settlement— Went up to Charles’s house after Sunset. He and his wife spent the Evening here.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued
20. 1689. 20. May. Vote of the Town of Braintree— Revolution of 1688.

“The Inhabitants of Braintree in the County of Suffolk in the Massachusetts Colony, in New England, being convened together, to give their Sentiments and Minds, about a present Settlement of a Government in the said Colony, until we shall receive orders from the crown of England &c— It was then voted in the affirmative— That their minds and requests are that the former Governor and Deputy with the Assistants and the Deputies of the towns chosen and sworn in 1686 be reinstated and have full power with the Representatives of the several Towns present; to make choice out of the Hond. Council, or other Gentlemen in the Colony to be Assistants, until further orders be given. We also declare that in case the Governor and Assistants, do not accept to be re-instated, that we give full power to the Hond. Council at Boston sitting, and the Representatives which we have sent to act for us in all matters that shall come under present consideration, in behalf of the Peace, safety and welfare of the Colony.
Also Voted that the Hon’d Waitstill Winthrop be Major General of the Militia of the Colony of the Massachusetts.

Christopher Webb and Joseph Crosbey were chosen by the Inhabitants, as their Representatives for the town of Braintree to meet the Representatives of the rest of the Towns at Boston on the 22d of this Instant May with full power to act as above expressed for the Town &c.
It was voted by the Inhabitants that Capt. Edmund Quincy should sign the return of the names of the Representatives and the order therein given them in the name of the Inhabitants.

1689 June 4. Braintree It being signified by Isaac Addington Clerk that the Council of safety and preservation of the Peace of the People, desired the Representatives of the Towns and Villages of the Massachusetts Colony should convene together at Boston to consult with the Council sitting in Boston fifth of this Instant June about the emergencies that come under consideration; there was chosen Christopher Webb Senr by the voice of the Assembly met, for their Representative”

These town votes are the only papers in the whole collection having any reference to political affairs—they relate to the overthrow of the Government of Sir Edmund Andros and shew that the inhabitants of Braintree entered heartily into that measure. The papers are in the hand writing of Norton Quincy
2. IV:45. Friday
Hingham— Cohasset fishing party.

Charles had an engagement of business in Boston; and declined going with me to Hingham and Cohassett— I took Thomas with me and leaving home a quarter past 6. A.M. reached Mr Loring’s at Hingham 9 minutes past seven Mr Quincy Thaxter and Mr Edward Thaxter soon came in— Quincy Thaxter took my place in my Chaise, and I rode with Mr Loring in his to Cohassett— Old blind Mrs Nicholls, at whose house we dined the two preceding years died last winter, and her house is shut up and empty— We dined at a small shed built by several of Hingham for the sole purpose of accommodating fishing parties. We went out in small row boats about two miles from the shore. Mr Stearns who is now preaching at the Church where Mr Charles Brooks was lately settled, Mr Baker, and Mr Morse all persons with whom I had no previous acquaintance were in the same boat with me. We changed our fishing ground three times with little success, but caught a few haddocks and perch—my portion was one hake, and one small cod. Mr Baker took the largest that was caught—a cat fish weighing perhaps ten pounds—black, goggle eyed and with a dorsal fin six inches high— Our boatman cautioned us not to approach too near his jaw, or he might take off one of our fingers— We returned to land between one and two O Clock, and dined upon Chowder, Claret and Champagne— After dinner we went upon the rocks, and fished again, with Poles, for perch with no better fortune— In the space of an hour and a half I took only two— At 4. P.M. the tide was up and the perch ceased to bite— We took a second dinner of fried perch: and at the earnest invitation of Mr Loring most of the company repaired to his house at Hingham, where we had tea, and coffee, and conversation till past 8 O’Clock— I had a dark ride home, not without danger of running foul of Chaises and Carryalls travelling the other way. The Quincy Curfew Bell of 9 P.M struck as we were approaching it, and when I reached home I found Charles and his wife there— Happy that the day had passed off without other accident than getting Sun burnt— The day had been calm and cool.
3. IV. Saturday.
Sun rose 4:54. Set 7:18. Day 14 hours 24 minutes—

I saw the Sun rise and set from the corner and porch of Charles’s house— Dr John Codman of Dorchester was here with two Scottish Gentlemen Mr Tawse an Advocate and Mr Lyon a Writer to the signet, or Attorney at Edinburgh— They came out in the Great Western, upon her last passage, as agents for the trustees of some charitable fund appropriated for Indians at Dartmouth College— They feel a particular solicitude for the remnant of the Seneca tribe, still lingering in the western part of the State of New-York, but upon whose lands a land company in that State have fixed their fangs, and whom the Government of the United States by a Schermerhorn Treaty are driving like a herd of cattle beyond the Mississippi. Dr Codman had been with these two Gentlemen to Hanover, New Hampshire and had seen at Dartmouth College two Indian Students, one of them in the Senior Class a Chief of the Seneca tribe quite an interesting young man named Pearce— I told them that the case of the Seneca Indians was hopeless. That a fraudulent Treaty coaxed, and bullied and bribed out of perhaps one tenth part of their chiefs and Warriors, was already sweeping them away beyond the Mississippi, and that there would soon be no trace of them left in the State of New-York as there is nothing left of the most powerful tribe of the Cherokees in Georgia. Such is the inexorable Law of the white man and the administration of the Government of the United States is moulded upon it— I mentioned the recent accounts in the Newspapers of the Execution according to Indian Law, that is the murder of Major Ridge, and his Son, and Elias Boudinot, by the party of their old Associate John Ross— They had been bullied, and bribed away beyond the Mississippi—had sold their Lands, themselves and their tribe to the abomination of Schermerhorns Treaty, and had paid the forfeit of their treachery with their lives— But the expulsion of the tribe from Georgia has been consummated, and they have gone to be finally exterminated beyond the Mississippi— They said the young chief at Dartmouth College, had expressed the same apprehension, and had told them that he had himself been offered five thousand dollars for his assent to the cession to the New-York land company and to the removal of the tribe West of the Mississippi— They seemed inclined to flatter themselves that the case was not quite so desperate as I believed it; but they were not sanguine in hope. I told them it was painful to me to speak of the treatment of the Indians by my countrymen; but it was in vain to disguise or suppress the truth— An inflexible determination to extirpate the race of Indian Savages was the white man’s law on this continent, and I feared would be so till the race itself shall be exterminated from the face of the Earth— These Gentlemen went from my house to the Stone meeting house to see the monument of my father and mother. Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon as I had sent to request he would, and budd several Apple trees in the garden and Nursery with yellow harvest buds, which Mr Loring gave me yesterday and with Spitzenberg buds which he brought with him. Also sundry Pear Stocks with Bartlett pear buds— Yesterday morning appeared the first flower upon on the Easternmost Althaea fronting my chamber window.
4. IV.15 Sunday
Sun rose 4:55. set 7:16. Day 14 hours 21 minutes. I saw him rise from Charles’s house—but not set.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from 1. Corinthians 10–31. “Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God.” It was communion day and an occasional sermon— The Communion was administered jointly, by Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt. The afternoon discourse was from 1 Corinthians 12.6. [“]And there are diversities of operations; but it is the same God which worketh all in all.” It was a discourse upon the power of religion in the heart of man— Well written—well reasoned and especially towards the close, animated and eloquent— The efficacy of religion in accomplishing all the great works of improvement in the condition of man throughout all ages was expounded with great elegance, and much classical illustration— I read the second of Dr Parker’s Sermons—on the distinction between Saints and Sinners—and there was nothing in it that made much impression upon my mind— There is a test to judge of the merit of Sermons, more effective than any critical standard, and that is what I remember of it. I think it doubtful whether I shall remember anything of Dr Parker’s Sermons In this Discourse he takes no small time of his auditory to convince them that they are, and necessarily must be either Saints or Sinners— It would seem to be hardly worthwhile to print a book of Sermons to prove this—for after all, there may be an intermediate class having no pretensions to peculiar sanctity and yet who cannot be classed exclusively with Sinners— He gives a judicious caution against excessive severity in estimating the characters of Sinners, and excessive indulgence to the Saints— He might have added that there is much of the Sinner in the holiest of this world’s Saints— I read also about half the Memoir of his Life by Professor Henry Ware junr and intended to read the remainder, but on returning home from Meeting this afternoon, I found Mr Degrand, with Mr Clapp the Editor of the Boston Saturday Evening’s Gazette, here and his Son— They spent the remainder of the afternoon, and took tea here, and walked round my garden and nursery grounds to inspect my seedling trees.— The solitary plum on the tree which I had always mistaken for a cherry-tree was shaken down yesterday, and Mr Greenleaf pronounced it a cherry or Canadian Plum. And this day I found a nest of rough yellowish caterpillar worms on one of my young Nettle trees— Mr Clapp particularly remarked my Shag bark walnut tree the nut of which was sown by me in October 1804.— Mr Degrand took a couple of Letters, one of which was for Gerrit Smith to deposite in the Post Office at Boston. I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s—where I found Louisa C. Smith—Charles and his wife, Mary, Mrs Angier from Medford; a young Spanish West Indian, with her, Mr E. Price Greenleaf and young Charles Miller— I walked home, with Mr Greenleaf and my Son Charles, and found his wife here; but he soon came for her, and they went up the hill— Degrand told me there was in one of the Newspapers a Letter from me on the subject of an astronomical Observatory.
5. IV:15. Monday.

My wife with Mary, Charles’s wife and Mary-Louisa went to Boston to pay sundry visits and returned to dine. After dinner I rode with Charles round through Milton and Dorchester, returning by the way of the granite bridge— I went to Charles’s house to see the Sunset, but he was beclouded. Edmund Quincy came there with his wife’s brotherParker, a youth of about 15 and we spent the Evening together in the porch— Edmund Quincy is the second and youngest Son of Josiah Quincy, President of Harvard University, about 30 years of age, a young man in imminent danger of losing his mind and his life in the visionary pursuit of unattainable perfection— He has plunged headlong into the two fashionable frenzies of the day the immediate abolition of Slavery, and the tetotalism of Temperance— He has suffered himself to be wheedled and brow beaten into the dreams of George Fox and Simon Menno, till upon mere religious principle he has become a Non-resistant, no-government, no-religion mono-maniac. He has fallen into all the deplorable excesses of the most inflammable abolition Societies, and has whipped his blood into such a fermentation that it has burnt through its natural channels, and brought on hemorrhages which have brought him to death’s door— His loss of blood was so great during the last winter, that he was for months confined to his house, and his residence at his father’s house this Summer has but partially restored him— He is now about to leave this town, and to remove to Dedham for a permanent residence— The widow Dowse a Sister of President Quincy’s mother has resided many years at Dedham, and died a few weeks since, leaving her estate there; and all her property which was large to him— He has given it for a residence to his son Edmund, who is to go there in a few weeks— He is a young man of the purest character and most amiable disposition—with much passive Fortitude; but no active energy; with little acuteness of penetration, a strong will and a weak judgment; too well fitted to be made an instrument of mischief in the hands of more crafty fanatics, who know how to turn their benevolent enthusiasm to the promotion of their private interest.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued—

21. 1670. and after— A small parcel of papers under one cover, of no value but as curiosities; being receipts of devises by Thomas Shepard, and other papers of Mrs Anna Shepard his widow, and Executrix. He died1677 before the marriage of Daniel Quinsey with his daughter— His son Thomas Shepard succeeded him as Minister of Charlestown, and died 7. June 1685— Among these papers are two Deeds of Land in Charlestown— I suppose the Will of her husband Thomas Shepard, must be recorded in the registry of Wills for the County of Middlesex at Cambridge. By one of the papers it appears that in Feby 1725. John Quincy was Guardian of Alice, widow of Samuel Shepard, daughter of Arthur Mason of Boston, baker
6. IV. Tuesday.

Yesterday was the anniversary of my departure for Russia in 1809— Since which thirty years, one generation of human life has passed away.— My Son Charles, then an infant, two years old, has now four children, the youngest of which has passed that age— The eldest is within one week of eight years old.— I had then two other sons both of whom lived to man’s estate, but whom it has pleased Heaven to transfer to the world of Spirits before their father— I think of them with infinite delight, and agonizing pain: submitting with resignation to the will of God, which has taken them from me, and living in humble hope of meeting them in bliss hereafter— With fervent supplication to Providence that, when I shall be taken away from the orphan daughter of my beloved child, they may not be left destitute of a protector, a guardian, and friend on earth or in Heaven— This day twenty two years have elapsed and the 23d. has commenced since my last return to my native Country— The eight years of my absence formed the most eventful and most prosperous period of my life; though strewed with bitter Afflictions— After my return I was 8 years Secretary of State; and four years President of the United States— These too were years of prosperity—though darkened with the decease first of my mother—then of my father, and finally by the desertion and treachery of a heartless world— The last ten years have been bound in shallows and in miseries—a perpetual struggle against the wind and tide of Fortune, and against all the baseness of the Times; unable to accomplish any of the good to my Country and to mankind which I have intensely desired, and unceasingly laboured to effect, alternately buffeted by all the political parties; occasionally bedaubed with fulsome flattery by those whom my opinions happen for the moment to suit, but hated and dreaded alternately by them all— During all this time the years of my natural life are drawing to a close— The world is departing from me, and I am not yet prepared to renounce the world— Work for your living was the motto to the day of my birth, and I must fulfil my destiny.— I think prospectively of the Hymn to Adversity, and for consolation repeat as Edmund Quincy did last Evening, the Stanza of the Castle of Indolence—“I care not, Fortune what you me deny.” I saw the Sun rise from Charles’s porch at 4:57—he set beclouded at 7:14.— day 14 hours 17 minutes Mr Lunt was here this morning, and borrowed a few more books for his centennial Sermon on the 29th. of September— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here. I took up again and wrote a few lines in the biography of my father— I had sent a copy of my Jubilee of the Constitution to Mr Harrison Gray Otis, and received this day an acknowledgment from him with remarks in that style of hyperbolical praise which he is accustomed to use, and in which he is not conscious of insincerity but which it is incumbent upon me to consider not as deliberate opinion, but as gentlemanly courtesy— The reception of that Discourse by the public is one of the multitude of events, even in this dark and declining stage of my existence, for which I can never be sufficiently grateful to God.
7. III:30. Wednesday

Morning beclouded with a sprinkling of rain— The ground thirsty for more— Four travelling quakers, two from Baltimore and two from Philadelphia, paid a morning visit to the Stone quarries and then to us. Deacon Spear was here and advised me to cut down the grove at the foot of Penn’s hill, near Henry Hardwick’s house— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon to bud trees, but the heat of the Sun was so intense that I ask him to come again next Saturday. Mr Beale came and introduced a young man from Kentucky who told me that Mr Graves had introduced him to me in the House of Representatives at Washington last Winter. Charles, his wife, and three elder children dined with us. Charles had been budding Apple and Pear trees near his house and in the cross-lane— I went with him in the Evening to Mr John Greenleaf’s, and spent an hour there— Mr Greenleaf is 75 years of age, and has been more than sixty years blind— He has in the last two or three years been losing his hearing, and has had two or more paralytic attacks— His wife is my Cousin Lucy Cranch; born in the same year about two months after me— Their younger Son Richard Cranch Greenleaf was there and MrPearce Cranch, a preacher of the gospel—and George Dawes, husband of their daughter Mary, and a daughter about 14—of their elder daughter Lucy Dawes. Mrs Greenleaf has two Portraits, in Crayons of my father and mother; which belong to me— They were taken in the year 1765. just after the birth of my sister Abigail— And Mrs T. B. Adams claims them, as having been given to her by my mother— They were taken by my Aunt Cranch from the House at the foot of Penn’s hill, when my mother was in England, to save them from the dampness of an empty house; and they have remained there about 55 years— Mr George Bancroft wishes to have this portrait of my father engraved to introduce it into his history of the United States; and I told Mrs Greenleaf I would send for it— I spoke also to Mrs Greenleaf about an Article published some time since in a Cincinnati newspaper—called the Courtship and marriage of the elder John Adams which J. A. Green the Editor of the Quincy Patriot some weeks since gave me, and said Augustus Whitney had asked him to republish as he understood with Mrs Greenleaf’s approbation— She said she had read the Article, and Frederic Augustus Whitney had spoken of it to her—but she had neither said nor heard any thing about its republication in the Quincy Patriot—to which however she had no objection— She agreed with me that it contained several errors in matter of fact, and I said I would return it to Mr Green, with notes to accompany the republication— Mrs Greenleaf said she had all the Letters from my mother when in England, to hers.
8. III:45. Thursday
Sun rose 4:59. Set 7:11. Day 14 hours 12. minutes.

I saw the Sunrise from the corner of Charles’s house, and remarked his rapid southing.— Sunset beclouded—a Mr Page came, with a subscription paper for a Unitarian monthly periodical, which I declined— Mr George Darracott came with Mr Buckingham as a Committee from the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association, who are to hold a biennial Fair in October; and invite me to deliver on that occasion, an Address before them; which I persisted in declining, though urged by Mr Darracott with great importunity— These invitations are all kindly intended, and it is painful to me to refuse them—but if I were to accept them all, it would turn me into an itinerant field preacher— I could do nothing else, and by frequent failure of performance should sink into contempt— I persisted in the refusal— In the Evening a young man by the name of Ward, from New York, brought a Letter of introduction from Freeman Hunt to my Son, who received him here. He is President of the Mercantile Library Association, and comes here in search of Lecturers for that institution— Mary with her daughter Mary Louisa, spent the day at Mrs T. B. Adams— Charles’s wife went in the Evening He was here— I was at the Bank this morning and deposited 115 dollars in gold.
List of Quincy family papers continued.
22. 1690. Augt. 4 and Septr. 18— Will of Daniel Quinsey

This is not one of the Mount Wollaston papers— In the diary of Chief Justice Sewall under the dates ofNovr. 1682 and 10. August 1690 are contained accounts of the marriage and of the death of Daniel Quinsey my great-grandfather’s father— Under date of 29 July, the judge intimates that he made his Will— On this hint I applied at the probate Office, and obtained this copy of the Will; to which Samuel Sewall’s name is appended as a subscribing witness— The testator describes himself as of Boston in the County of Suffolk in New-England, Goldsmith— There are in this Will, and in the very few incidents of Daniel Quinsey’s life which I have been able to collect circumstances deeply affecting, and leading to painful conjectures. Edmund Quinsey, his father, born in 1628. in the 20th. year of his age 26. July 1648 was married to Joanna Hoar, born in 1625, and consequently 3 years older than himself— She bore him twelve children 4 Sons and 8. daughters, of whom Daniel the eldest Son was born 12. Septr. 1658— Two other Sons both named Edmund died under one and two years of age— John born 3. April 1652 died 14. August 1674 So that of all the Sons born of that marriage Daniel was the only one who lived to be married— His father did not give him a liberal education; but put him an apprentice to John Hull who had married his Sister Judith, and as Hull made his fortune by coining the pine tree shillings, 6 pences and 3 pences, perhaps Daniel was nearer to friendship with Mammon, as apprentice to John Hull, than he would have been at Harvard College.
