9. III:30. Friday.

Mr John J. Carr, who rents my farm, and is my next door neighbour had a son born about six weeks since— The child died the Evening before last, and was buried this day— I called yesterday at his house to see him— He was gone out, but I saw Mrs Carr, and the infant in its last sleep— I condoled with the mother, whom I found composed and resigned— Her loss is peculiarly distressing, the child being an only one, born after many years of marriage. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I dined with him— He brought me a Treasury Note of 1000 dollars—issued 17. May last—of which I hold 100 dollars as Administrator of Thomas Boylston 157:26. as Executor of my father’s Will; and the rest on my own account. Josiah Adams 2d. was here this morning having completed his arrangements for obtaining the patent for his vertical bark cutter— I enclosed his Petition and specification, with a check on the Bank of Washington for 10 dollars, and the drawing rolled round a staff, to H. L. Ellsworth the Commissioner of Patents— The model, he is to send to the Collector of the Customs at Boston— There was a thick fog this morning—then distant thunder—two light showers; followed by a brisk North western gale which swept off all the clouds and left a clear autumnal evening— The Sun rose at 5. and set 7:9. but was behind the western hill, before I reached Charles’s porch— He and his wife passed the Evening here— Experiment of making soil with street dust and pond mud.
Daniel Quinsey.

Joanna the first wife of Edmund Quinsey, bore her last child, Esther 24. March 1667.—and died on the 16th. of May 1680. at the age of 55. In less than 7 months from that day, on the 8th. of December 1680. Edmund Quinsey married Elizabeth Gookin; by whom he had 3 children. Edmund born 24. October 1681— John born 15. April 1683. and Mary born 7. Decr. 1684.— When on the 9th. of November 1682 Daniel Quinsey was married to Anna Shepard at Captain Brattle’s house, the company present was so numerous that they almost filled the great Hall; but neither Edmund Quinsey the father, nor any one person of his family appears to have been there— It was two years after the father’s marriage to Elizabeth Gookin, and Edmund, the son by that marriage was just turned of one year old.— The most melancholy sudden death of Mrs Brattle, at this wedding, turned it to a day of lamentation and mourning— Yet was it a well assorted marriage; and how much reason have I to bless God that it took place.— Daniel Quinsey died of a consumption in the 40th. year of his age— On the 10th. of June 1690. Chief Justice Sewall, with his wife took in his Coach Daniel Quinsey sick, out to his fathers at Braintree.— On the 16th. of July Daniel Quinsey returns to Boston in a boat, apparently alone, worse than when he went dies on the 10th. and is buried on the 12th. of August, in the tomb of John Hull; in the granary burying ground at Boston— Many persons present at the funeral; but neither Edmund Quincy the father nor any individual of the family.— With what? indifference, they must have seen him die! (pass to
10. III:15. Saturday.

Clear morning. I went up the hill, half an hour before sunrise to ascertain if Sirius would be visible— Rigel, Betelgeuse and the belt of Orion were the indicators where he would rise, but he was not discernible till the Stars in the belt were lost in the dawn. Mr Peter Whitney was here, but I did not see him— This afternoon Mr E. Price Greenleaf came, and budded 8 seedling Apple trees in the Seminary with buds of the golden Russetten, from slips sent me by Mr Brooks of Medford; and some from Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and of his yellow harvest apple, I went with Charles, his wife, and Mary, who had dined at Charles’s, to Weymouth and visited Mrs Mercy Tufts— She is suffering much from inflammation of the eyes— Her daughters Mercy and Susan were with her— Returning home we stopped at Mrs T. B. Adams’s to take up the children Fanny and Louisa Catherine who had passed the day there— Found Mr Joseph Harrod there. Charles and I walked thence home— He and his wife passed the Evening here.
Daniel Quinsey’s Will.

1690. 4. August Chief Justice Sewall was with Daniel Quinsey at his death, Sunday 10. August 1690. about 7. O’Clock in the Evening— He had been with him that morning—read the 102 and began the 103d. Psalm. prayed and returned home. The 102d. Psalm is entitled—“a prayer for the afflicted; when he is overwhelmed; and poureth out his complaint before the Lord[”]— The beginning of the 103d. is a blessing upon God for his mercy— Mr Sewall put up a bill for Daniel Quinsey at his request, just after contribution in the afternoon was called out (of meeting) his Cousin being very bad, and prayed at his request.— Mr Willard, Minister of the old South Church was sent for and prayed— The dying man pulled out his hand, gave it to Mr Willard, and seemed to pray, himself— His aunt Judith Hull was also with him at his Death.— The Diary says—[“]I have parted with a cordial fast friend, such an one as I shall hardly find[”]—and adds—[“]Cousin was concerned what he should do for Patience—but God graciously furnished him, and has now translated him to that state and place wherein he has no occasion for any.”— The Preamble to the Will attests the piety of the Testator. It constitutes his wife sole Executrix—bequeath’s the use of his whole Estate, real and personal for her support and the maintenance of their two children, till they come of age or be married; and then he bequeaths his house in Boston to his Son John, and the rest of his Estate in 3 equal parts, between his wife and two children— His daughter Anna was then five years old, and he specially bequeaths to her a bed and bedding, and his small bible with silver clasps— His son John was an infant under two years of age, and to him he bequeaths Pole’s annotations on the Bible and his arms,— Not a word of notice is taken either of his father or of either of his Sisters— His half brother, Edmund was then in the ninth year of his age— On the 10th. of March 1691 it appears by the Diary that his widow removed to Charlestown, with her children and goods.
11. III:30 Sunday

Sun rose clear 5.2. Set 7.8. beclouded. Day 14 hours 6. min. Conjunction of Moon and Mercury— Saw the moon; but the clouds intercepted the view\ of the planet.— Heard Mr Lunt A.M from Jonah 4.9. [“]And God said to Jonah Dost thou well to be angry for the gourd? and he said I do well to be angry even unto death.” Mr Lunt commented upon the whole book of Jonah, which he said was rather a history of the prophet than a prophesy— He spoke of the difficulties, of the narrative of facts; and of the conjectures of commentators to solve them— That it was an Allegory—or a Parable like those in which Christ was accustomed to convey instruction— That the whale was an Inn where Jonah was confined, after his confinement, and the like— All this was perfectly immaterial to the moral lesson taught by the whole book—which is as precious as any other portion of Scripture of the same extent.— The lesson is two-fold— Of obedience, and of resignation to the Will of God— Jonah was an Hebrew, but his prophesy was against Nineveh, the Capital of Assyria— The prophesy of Jonah is said to have been 802 years before Christ. The captivity of the kingdom of Israel by Tiglath Pilneser and Shalmaneser, Assyrian kings was 721 years before Christ; and the captivity of Zedekiah king of Judah, by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon 588 before Christ— Another prophesy of Jonah is mentioned 2. Kings 14:25. but that related to the restoration of Hamath to the kingdom of Israel, by Jeroboam the second. Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from Mark 7:11. “But ye say, If a man shall say to his father or mother, It is Corban, that is to say a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me; he shall be free.” There appears to be no difference of opinion as to the meaning of this passage, but in the original the sentence is incomplete, and all the translators interpolate words to make it intelligible— There is some obscurity with regard to the import of the word Corban, which is used in no other passage of the Bible—but the meaning is to be settled by the context— Mr Lunt remarked upon the extreme severity of the reproaches of Jesus upon the Pharisees contrasted with his habitual tenderness and indulgence to repenting Sinners. All the bitterness of his censure for the self righteous, and hypocritical— Mr Lunt dwelt with great emphasis and solemnity of manner upon the obligations of filial duty and upon the baseness of neglecting them upon the pretence of religion— At home I read the 3d. Sermon in the Volume by Dr Nathan Parker, and finished the Memoir of his life by Professor Henry Ware junr— I read also the greater part of two manuscript Sermons, preached by my grandfather William Smith, to his flock at Weymouth on the New-Years day of 1781. He had then been 47 years the Minister of that Church; and the Sermons contain a biographical sketch of his predecessors in the ministry there— Mr Joseph Harrod and Elizabeth C. Adams at Charles’s—
12 III:15. Monday.

Showery— Overstrained exercise in dressing a seminary ring for plantation— A man by the name of Wyman came, and introduced himself to me, as he said merely from an overruling desire to see me— His conversation was strange but not interesting; and although not entirely disjointed and foolish yet of so little spirit that it left me in doubt whether he was fuddled or half-witted— He said he had led a wandering life the last 13 or 14 years, never six months in the same place— That he came three years since from the State of Illinois, and was roaming about the Country— I asked him if he preached. He said, yes, when he could get an audience; which was not often— But he occasionally had addressed numerous assemblies. As he was going away he said that in his youth he had been a student at Harvard College— On looking into the Catalogue, I found his name in the Class, graduated in 1825 of which my Son, Charles was a member. He said not a word of that to me— About Sunset I went to Charles’s house, and took a ride with him to Braintree— He and his wife spent the Evening here— He remembered Wyman, but not with much commendation.
List of Quincy family papers continued
23. 1697. 11. December— Will of Edmund Quinsey.

Edmund Quinsey died 7. January 1698. between 7 and 8 O’Clock in the Evening. He left his real Estate in Braintree, except a tract of about 40 Acres, to his wife, and her Son, Edmund then in the 17th. year of his age, and to him the survivorship in fee— And in the event of his dying without issue—all the Estate not disposed of by him by Deed or Will, is given to his Grandson John, son of Daniel Quinsey, in fee. He bequeaths also to John, then in his ninth year two hundred pounds; but in the Event of the real Estate’s coming to him the two hundred pounds, were to be distributed in seven equal parts between the seven surviving children of the testator, or their heirs or assigns, not including those of Edmund the Son, or of Judith Reyner.— The seven Devisees are not named in the Will—but they were, besides John himself, Ruth Hunt, Experience, Esther and Mary— There were besides these Joanna, Elizabeth and Anna, one of whom, I know not which, had died in 1675—the other two were of these seven devisees—but the device never took effect. Elizabeth wife of the Testator; and her son Edmund are appointed Executrix and Executor of the Will; she to have full power to act alone until he shall come of Age. The reserved 40 acre lot was given to the Testator’s daughter Ruth Hunt. 105 pounds to his youngest daughter Mary. His negro boy Peter to his Grandson John if he should come of age; and a piece of plate value 45 shillings to the Church of Brantrey.— The probate of the Will is dated 31. March 1698. by Elizabeth Quinsey alone, and the whole administration committed to her until her son Edmund shall be of age— Chief Justice Sewall in entering on his diary of 8 January 1798 the death of Edmund Quinsey adds “A true New England man, and one of our best friends is gone.” His funeral was on the 12th. of January 1698.
13. IV. Tuesday

Showery morning— Afterwards cleared away— My Son Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine’s birth-day 8. Mr Smith of Kentucky and Mr Brashear of Louisiana, travelling in these parts, came from Boston upon visits of civility to me and to the stone quarries— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I wrote by him a note to Mr Curtis promising to meet him and Mr Fuller, at Charles’s Office in Court Street N. 23. next Friday morning at 10.— Upon a Letter of expostulation and exhortation from my wife, I resumed the writing upon the biography of my father, but have been yesterday and this day, afflicted with rhumatics, occasioned by over exercise yesterday morning in my seminary— Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks with their daughter were at Charles’s this afternoon— I went up the hill after Sunset, and Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued
24. 1709. 30. May. Mrs Anna Shepard’s Will

Mrs Shepard, survived her husband about 32. years— She survived also, her son-in-Law, Daniel Quinsey, about 20 years; and her daughter his widow, about two years. She, the daughter in 7 [symbols] 1700 had been married to Moses Fiske, the Minister of the Church at Braintree, and by him had two children Shepard and Margaret Fiske— Mrs Shepard in her will styles herself of Milton. On the 18th. of January 1705 her granddaughter, Anna Quinsey had been married to John Holman of Milton, and probably after the death of her daughter, Mrs Fiske, perhaps before, she had removed to Milton and lived with Mrs Holman, who survived her and died 8. Octr. 1717. aged 92.— The first bequest in Mrs Shepard’s Will, is of all her houses and Lands in Charlestown to her grand daughter Anna Smith wife of Henry Smith of Long-Island— Mrs. Shepard had a son named Thomas, who succeeded his father as Minister of Charlestown born 1658. and died 7. June 1685. aged 27. This Mrs Anna Smith was perhaps his daughter. The next bequest is to her Grandson John Quinsey, student at Harvard College, of the farm at Mount Wollaston, charged with the payment of sixteen pounds a year during the minority of her grand children Shepard Fiske and Margaret Fiske towards the charge of their bringing up.— Of two hundred pounds to Shepard Fiske at 21. and the same sum to Margaret Fiske at 18.— And 220 pounds to her grand daughter Holman 100 pounds in one year and 120 pounds in 2 years after her decease— There were contingent devises which never took effect—40 shillings each to Revd Peter Thacher Minister at Milton to Revd. Simon Bradstreet, Minister of Charlestown and to Mrs Anne Fiske of Brantrey— John Quinsey is appointed sole Executor of the Will— The copy without probate is certified by Paul Dudley, Regr. and endorsed in the hand-writing of John Quincy “Grandmother Shepard’s Will. Copy.”— He had taken his first degree at Harvard College in 1708. and was in the 21st. year of his age when his Grandmother died, and left him the Estate at Mount Wollaston, which until then had always been tenanted by persons of the name of Spear, but of which he then took possession, and resided thereon till his death on the 13th of July 1767.
14. IV: Wednesday

A man by the name of Peleg Clarke, a sort of literary sailor very shabbily attired came and brought with him a folio manuscript volume of his own writing, apparently a diary; which he said he intended to publish, and of which he expected to sell 2000 copies— He was a Seaman in a public ship, in the last War, with Great-Britain, and was taken in a privateer, and confined in Dartmoor prison— He said he had in his book an exact account of what was called the Dartmoor Massacre, which was no Massacre at-all— The whole affair had been grossly falsified, but his book would rectify it all, by his testimony as an eye witness of the whole transaction.— He said he had a petition before Congress praying an allowance of wages for privateersmen from the Seamans fund, in which by a report from the Secretary of the Navy, it appeared there was 50,000 dollars with only five pensioners quartered upon it— He gave me to read in his book, what he said was a copy of his petition; but it was in the form of a statement respecting the navy pension fund, and an argument for the application of it to the payment of wages to privateersmen— Of the standard of his literary qualifications it may serve as a sample that in discoursing about the definitive Treaty of Peace he uniformly calls it the indefinite Treaty of Peace— He said his petition had been presented in 1836 by Mr Dutee J. Pearce, and referred to the Committee of naval affairs—but nothing further had been done with it;—that last winter Mr Cranston had the charge of it with no better success— He said perhaps it might be better for him to prepare a new and different petition, to give Congress the pleasure of variety.— I told him that was unnecessary; but if he desired it, I would at the next Session, call his old Petition up, and move its reference to the naval committee; and do what might be proper; and in my power to support it— He thanked me; and said he would perhaps go to Washington himself next winter—but now he wanted to get home at Clinton 13 miles from Utica in the State of New-York, and would be glad to have pecuniary assistance— He could not do any hard labour being troubled with a Hernia— He told his Story also to Charles—Mr and Mrs Lunt— Charles, his wife and three children dined, and spent the day with us.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued—
25. 1712. 21. August. Thomas Brattle’s Account for Guardianship of John Quinsey.

This account was on two folio sheets of paper, the second of which only remains. The whole credit side however is on the last page.— The first credit charge is dated 28 Oct: 1708. and the last debet 25. June 1711. I suppose the guardianship commenced immediately after the death of John Quinsey’s mother Mrs Fiske— Most of the debtor charges are for payments in Execution of Mrs Shepard’s Will— The bequest of 40 shillings to Mrs Anne Fiske, is charged 22. June 1710. as paid to Mrs Anne Marsh. Hence I infer that in the interval she had been married to Joseph Marsh, Mr Fiske’s successor in the ministry who was ordained 18. May 1709. and who died 8. March 1726.— From the dates of the payments for Shepard and Margaret Fiske it appears that Mrs Shepard died on the 5th of Feby 1710
15. IV. Thursday

Suffering with the lumbago, in punishment of over exercise in the morning before breakfast to improve the soil of my plantations.— I receive last week a Letter from a Committee of the Erodelphian Society of Miami University, Oxford Ohio, informing me of my election to deliver the anniversary Address before that Society on the 8th of August 1840—and yesterday, I received an invitation to deliver an introductory Lecture on the 21st. or 28th. of October next to the Lyceum at Worcester in this Commonwealth.— I did not find time to make my acknowledgments for these honorary distinctions, and this day received a Letter from Mr Benjamin D. Silliman a member of the House of Assembly of New-York requesting copies of my recent Letters to my Constituents, meaning the abolition Petitioners—to which I began the answer, but it intercepted the writing of my fathers biography— This day one of the fluted granite pillars for the New-York exchange passed by my house on its way from the quarries cased up in a wooden frame bound with iron hoops—drawn upon a hurdle by thirty five yoke of oxen and five horses—going to be ship’d at Bent’s point in a Schooner for New-York— It weighs as Josiah Adams junr. told me 32 seat long and five feet in diameter at the base—weighs thirty two tons, the geneal weight of the stone here being 13 cubic feet to a ton— Another pillar of the same dimensions is to follow tomorrow—the two to be shipped on the deck of the Schooner; one on the starboard; and the other on the larboard side— The bell of the Stone Meeting house was rung as it passed by— I was up at Charles’s porch just after Sunset, and he and his wife spent the Evening here.
Mount Wollaston papers— John Quincy

In the Diary of Chief Justice Samuel Sewall, under date of 4. Octr. 1715 is the following entry— I lent Major John Quincey five pounds; and gave him a Psalm book covered with Turkey leather (Morocco) for his mistress—
This mistress was Elizabeth Norton daughter of John Norton, Minister of the first Church at Hingham—to whom John Quincy was married on the1716—

It is characteristic of the age and Country that a handsomely bound Psalm-book should be deemed an acceptable present from a gentleman lover to his sweet heart—especially at second hand from a learned judge Among the Mount Wollaston papers are six Letters one, from John Norton to his Sister dated Hingham 23. September 1678.— One from S. Shepard to his Sister Mary Norton dated Woodbridge New Jersey 17. June 1704, and four from John Norton Junr. to his father and Aunt written in 1709
16. IV. Friday

I went to Boston this morning with Charles, and returned home to dine. Called to visit Mr George Blake, who is confined to his house lame, by a fracture of his leg last winter, from a fall on the steps of the State house to which he was going as a member of the State Senate— Crippled the remainder of his life— His servants told me that he was asleep, and did not usually rise till between 1. and 2. P.M— At the savings Bank, I took a minute of the state of my Accounts there— At the chamber of the Historical Society, I took out a volume of funeral Sermons containing that of John Hancock upon Edmund Quincy, delivered at Braintree 23. April 1738. and intituled The instability of Humane Greatness.— Mr Quincy was the agent of the Province, and died of the small pox at London 23 Feby 1737. 8— I found Mr N. Curtis at Charles’s Office; and Mr Fuller, a Master builder at Medford, who married a daughter of the late Moses Gill, soon came in— Mr Curtis had informed him of the sum recovered in the name and right of Thomas Boylston from the French Government, and subsequently much reduced, from Petty Vaughan—and of the portion of it, which was due to the legal representative of Lieutt. Governor Moses Gill—and I conversed with him upon the necessity that administration Letters should be taken out on the Estates both of Governor Gill, and of his Executor and residuary legatee the late Moses Gill— Mr Fuller, married one of his daughters— Another daughter married a man named Cobb, and there is a Son, surviving named also Moses Gill; they live at Groton. I advised that the three heirs of the late Moses Gill, should jointly make application to the Judge of Probate for Worcester County for Letters of Administration upon both Estates—and promised when they shall have agreed upon the person who shall petition for the Letters, to prepare for them a statement to the judge in support of the petition— I shewed to Mr Fuller the power of Attorney from the late Moses Gill to me given in June 1830. and mentioned the Note from him to Mrs Boylston to be deducted from the sum payable to his representative, on the obligation, of Thomas Boylston— He said he would confer with all the heirs of the late Moses Gill, and inform me as soon as possible of their determination— I then called at Mr John Pickering’s Office, and saw his Son— He himself was absent at Salem— I then called twice on Dr Francis Parkman, and agreed with him to report next Thursday, at the adjourned meeting of the board of Overseers of Harvard University, the confirmation of all the proposed Doctorates of Law and of Divinity. Dr Parkman said he knew this to be also the opinion of Mr. Pickering— I visited also Dr George Parkman, and engaged to dine with him next Thursday.— Met separately Mr P C Brooks, T. Greenleaf Edmund Quincy, and Dr Frothingham, at whose house I partially examined the first volume of the Records of the first Church, of which he is now the Minister— I found entries of the baptism of Elisabeth, daughter of William Ting 10. 1st mo. 1639— This was Thomas Brattle’s wife—and of Anna 12. day 11. mo 1639. She married Thomas Shepard— Cold Easterly storm of rain after dinner and Evening
17. IV. Saturday

Cold, dull, dry, easterly storm; and the day passed off like almost all others, in what is no better than absolute idleness. After dinner, I took my Town and County, and Parish tax-bills to the Town hall, where the Selectmen, and Assessors hold meetings every Saturday afternoon from 4 to 7. O’Clock, to ascertain the particulars upon which the bills were made up— The town and county tax is 414 dollarsand the Parish tax 210— I found there William B. Duggan, and James Newcomb two of the Selectmen, who are also the representatives of the town in the State Legislature— The Selectmen are the Assessors of the town and County tax— The Parish Assessors are different; chosen by the several congregations; but Mr Newcomb is also one of them— I left with him my parish tax to have the particulars endorsed upon it; and the bill for the town and County tax with Dr Duggan for the same purpose— I am to call upon them for the bills next Saturday. My town and County tax is for 15000 dollars of real Estate, and 75000 personal. but I am yet to enquire 1. what was the sum voted by the town to be raised for the service of this year; and of the last. 2. The Law for the Assessment of the tax— The amount which they have added to my valuation the present year— Dr Duggan said it was 1000 dollars to the personal property and no more— And the reason assigned for this was that the Assessors concluded that my income made addition to my property; at the close of the year.— Dr Duggan said the town had foolishly voted to raise a sum this year fifty per cent more than that of last year— I called on Mr Lunt, and left with him Deanes History of Scituate— He had a Volume of the Church records of Milton, into which I looked to see if I could find any notice of John Holman and his wife John Quincy’s Sister— Her name was not there, but John Holman was entered as admitted a member of the Church Jany 1718 which was immediately after his wife’s death— Mr Lunt had some verses signed J. P. in the hand-writing of Joseph Parmenter formerly one of the Town Clerks— Mr Stearns, now preaching at Hingham, in the parish late Mr Charles Brooks’s came in while I was there— He exchanges with Mr Lunt to morrow— I called at Charless about Sunset— His wife and Mary spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s—and he at Mr William Appleton’s.
Children of John Quincy and Elizabeth Norton
1. Norton Quincy born1717 married 12. Feby 1746 to Martha Salisbury by Revd. Joseph Sewall D.D. died at Quincy 29. Septr. 1801.
2. Anna Quincy—baptized 24. May 1719.—married 24. Feby 1744 to Coll. John Thaxter of Hingham
3. Elizabeth Quincy baptised 17. Decr 1721. married 16. October 1740. to Revd William Smith, Minister at Weymouth died 1. Octr 1778
4 Lucy Quincy, baptized 7. December 1729. marriedNovember 1755 to Doctor Cotton Tufts of Weymouth— Died 30 October 1785
Joanna Quincy, baptized 23. March 1735.
18. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Stearns from Hingham, in the morning from 1. John 4.20. “For he that loveth not his brother whom he hath seen, how can he love God, whom he hath not seen” and in the afternoon from John’s Gospel 15.5. “For without me ye can do nothing:” Plain good sense and morals— Mr Stearns dined with us.— I read the 4th. Sermon of Dr. Parker—from Ecclesiastes 7:10. [“]Say not thou, what is the cause, that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this.”— Its title is, erroneous comparisons of the present with the past— I have recently made an application of the same passage of Scripture; but Dr Parker’s discourse upon it appears to me superficial. I read also the Extracts from the Letters of Dr Parker, appended to the Memoir of his life, by Professor Henry Ware junr— Dr Parker was born 5. June 1782. and died 8. Novr. 1833— This may be considered a long life— Yet I was born 15 years before, and have now survived him nearly 6. years— I have been indulged thus with 21 years more of life than he— Has my time been as well employed as his?

I saw the Sun set from Charles’s porch at 6.58. directly behind the summit of the sloping hill, North and westerly from the porch— Charles’s birthday 32. Mr E. Price Greenleaf spent the Evening with us.

list.head: List of Mount Wollaston papers continued
list.item: 1767. 27. July John Quincy died on the 13th. of July 1767.

div.p: Bequeaths his personal Estate, to Elizabeth his wife and one half the profits and improvement of the mount Wollaston farm, for her life, and with this reservation the same Estate in fee to his Son Norton Quincy; together with the Lands in the 600 acres and at Aldridge’s farm, the cedar swamp in the middle and round swamps in Braintree—and his books armour and apparel.— To his three daughters Anna Thaxter, Elizabeth Smith and Lucy Tufts, lands in the District of New Braintree near the town of Brookfield in Worcester County, and 185 acres of land laid out to him, to satisfy in part a grant of 500 acres made to him by the great and general Court of the Province in 1735 situate on the South bounds of the town of Northfield in the County of Hampshire—and also the proceeds of the sale of nine tenths of the land at Shedds neck, amounting to £720 all to be equally divided between them— To his Son Norton two Negro Man Servants and to his wife one Negro woman Servant, the profits of their labour to be enjoyed equally between his wife and Son— To his brother Shepard Fiske and to his Sister Margaret Bucknam each a gold ring— To the first Church in Braintree ten pounds to purchase a piece of plate for the Lord’s table— His Son Norton is the universal residuary Legatee; and he and his mother are made joint Executor and Executrix of the Will— Norton Quincy alone presented the Will for probate, and Administration was granted jointly to him and his mother.
19. IV:15. Monday

Morning fog, followed by a clear day, bright Sun, and pleasant Evening. Mr Lunt was here, and looked over the Volumes of the third series of the Massachusetts historical Society, and borrowed the volume of funeral Sermons containing that of Mr Hancock upon judge Edmund Quincy I spoke to him again about the administration of the communion on the 29th. of September— He said he had spoken of it to Mr Whitney and they had agreed to give notice the Sunday before that the communion would be then administered. I asked him if a vote of the Church would not be necessary.— This had not occurred to him; but he said it might be easily taken, by asking the members of the Church to stay after the morning service, a fortnight before the day— Mr Francis Jackson, and Mr Edmund Quincy visited me with Mr John Scoble an English abolitionist who has been travelling in the West Indies, and has been about a month in this Country, lecturing upon abolition— Mr Scoble was going this afternoon for New-York and is to embark in the Liverpool Steam-packet for England, on the 24th.— Mr Quincy said they had induced Mr Scoble to come out to give me any information that I might desire concerning the condition of the English Islands where Slavery has been abolished. I had much conversation with him— His reports upon the condition of the Island, and all rose-coloured as to the results of emancipation; but he is evidently a prejudiced, and interested witness— As to the ultimate issue, he admitted that the Islands must finally pass into the exclusive possession of a mongrel half-breed of African and European blood from which the white race will gradually retire; but will not be expelled: and that as a further necessary consequence the Colonial Supremacy of England over them will cease— I spoke of the despotic measures of the English Ministry, suppressing the Legislature of the Island of Jamaica, to carry through the emancipation Laws, and of the convulsions in the English Government itself occasioned thereby— He said that it was all occasioned by the intractable obstinacy of the Legislative Assembly of Jamaica in resisting an act of Parliament for the reform of the Prison— The proposal had only been to suspend the Legislative Assembly of Jamaica, for two years and a half, to which it had been reduced from 5 years— The bill had finally passed in the house of commons by a majority of ten; but had been thrown out, with the exception of a single Section by the House of Peers— Mr Scoble was much dissatisfied with the compensation granted by the British Parliament to the emancipated Slaves masters, which he said was carried entirely by intrigue, against the will of the abolitionists.— The conversation was animated, but good humoured, and we parted with all the forms of politeness, and civility— This afternoon, Mr James Prince, a Grandson of the James Prince, who was heretofore, Marshal of the United States, brought me a Letter from his Grandmother Mrs Agnes Prince, widow of the marshal, requesting a Letter of recommendation to the Secretary of War, in aid of an application for a Commission of 2d. Lieutenant in the army, which I gave him— He had similar Letters from Mr Richard Fletcher and Postmaster Green— I Saw Miss Sampson at Charles’s. He and his wife spent the Evening here—
20. IV:45. Tuesday
Sun rose 5:11 Set 6:55—day 13 hours 44 minutes—

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I gave him, the two Quit-claim deeds of Mrs Alicia Boylston, and of John Lane Boylston and Ward Nicholas Boylston of the farm at Weston, to have them recorded, in the Registry of Deeds for the County of Middlesex. He brought out with him a Letter to me, from J. H. Hacket, dated 24 31. July London, upon the character of Hamlet in reply to my Letter to him ofFebruary last— This Letter was brought by the Steam packet, which arrived at New-York at Midnight of Sunday; and with it came intelligence of the death on theof June of the Turkish Sultan Mahmoud, of a total defeat of his troops by the Viceroy of Egypt, and of popular riots at Birmingham in England— Morning visit from Revd. Dr Storrs, with his Son, Coll. Minott Thayer and Mr Spalding of Braintree who came to claim the performance of a promise which I made last fall, to deliver an Address to the People of that Town, sometime before the meeting of Congress, this year— I acknowledged the promise, and said I would endeavour to perform it— I felt myself bound to except Braintree from the general rule which I have been obliged to prescribe to myself of declining all invitations, to deliver Addresses, Lectures and Orations.— Braintree was the name of my native town; and although Quincy has since been detached from it, I still consider Braintree as my own mother town; having claims upon me possessed by none other— I requested however that it might not be expected I should discourse upon any political subject, and that no notice should be taken of it in the newspapers, at least until very shortly before the day, which Mr Thayer said it would be difficult to prevent— We had much political conversation, of little value— While we were at dinner, the Revd. Mr Wheeler, now of Washington in Pennsylvania, brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Wilson heretofore a member of Congress from that District— Mr Wheeler’s object was to levy a contribution, for establishing a college at a small town in Virginia bordering upon that part of Pennsylvania—perhaps Morgantown. I declined subscribing, as I am often compelled to do, from absolute destitution of means, and persisted in my refusal though urged with great importunity by Mr Wheeler— He said he was originally from Massachusetts and lived in Boston till the Chesapeake frigate was taken by the Shannon in the summer of 1813— Since then he has lived, settled as a methodist preacher at Washington Pennsylvania, and is now to be a teacher at this College in Virginia. He had also a Letter from Mr Joseph Johnson the member of Congress from that District to Mr Josep Dutee J. Pearce of Newport.— As I declined contributing he asked for Letters of recommendation to any of my friends in Boston, but I told him I could not recommend to my friends what I declined to do myself.— He asked me to return him the Letter from Mr Wilson, which I did.— After Sunset at Charles’s porch— He and his wife here for the Evening.
21. III:30 Wednesday—
Saw Sirius 15 minutes risen at 4. A.M

I mark the 12th. of this month as the day when Sirius would have been visible if the weather had been clear—but there has not been a clear morning before Sunrise since the 11th. till this day. I marked this morning from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house the relative location of the Star, which when 15 minutes risen was right over the turret of the Temple.

President Quincy called here this morning just as I was finishing breakfast, to converse with me upon sundry concerns of the University— First of the nominations for the Doctorates; upon which I told him that the Committee had agreed to report the confirmation of them all— Then he said he was about to propose and to undertake the erection of an Astronomical Observatory at Cambridge; and to engage the services of Mr Bond as an Observer— That he had conversed with Mr Bond on the subject—who was willing to engage upon moderate terms; and was now engaged in making Astronomical Observations for the Government of the U.S. Mr Quincy said he proposed to commence upon a small scale, and should offer a Subscription Paper, without reference to the offer heretofore made by me, which was a subscription of 1000 dollars— But for that and various other reasons he should present the subscription paper first to me— I told him I rejoiced and was exceeding glad, that he had taken this matter in hand— That he would have my hearty good wishes for the success of his undertaking, and I would subscribe to the extent of my ability, which was not now quite equal to what it was when I made the former offer— I had morning visits from Mr Jeremiah Mason and Mr Amos Lawrence of Boston, and also of a young man from Philadelphia named Bower, whose only motive was curiosity.— At 4 this afternoon Mr Thomas Greenleaf called at my house and rode with me to the House of Mr Noah Curtis who is the Town Treasurer and ex officio Treasurer of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund— At the last meeting of the Supervisors which was in 1835. Mr Thomas Greenleaf and myself were appointed a committee to examine and report on the Treasurers accounts— There was then a balance short of 500 dollars in his hands, which has now accumulated to more than one thousand— They consist principally of Notes upon interest from Mr Curtis himself as Treasurer of the Town, and he was much puzzled to settle whether he could sue himself. I should think that an investment in some other stocks yielding six per Cent would be preferable to Town Treasury Notes.— We found the accounts properly kept and correctly cast up, and so certified on the back of the leaf upon which the Accounts were entered— We returned home about 6. and I promised to inform Mr Greenleaf of the day of the week in the week after next when I wish the Supervisors of the fund to hold their meeting— Mrs T. B. Adams and her daughter Elizabeth were here this Evening— It was the warmest summer day, that we have had this Season, though refreshed by a light easterly wind.— I finished my Letter to Mr Benjn D. Silliman, and wrote a short Letter to George Taylor of Georgetown, and one to the Revd. Orange Scott, of Lowell— I have turned to Reading Prescott’s Ferdinand and Isabella.
22. III:15 Thursday
Saw Sirius again III:45.

I rode to Boston, in Charles’s four wheel chaise, our Coachman Thomas driving me with one of our Coach horses— I went immediately to Charles’s Office where I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis. He was prepared to make the transfer of Shares of the U.S. Bank to Mr John Lowell for the settlement of his charges for compensation, upon the Executors of Ward N. Boylston— Mr Lowell had agreed to receive the Bank shares at the rate at which we had taken them, since which their price in the market has fallen five and a half-per cent— Mrs Boylston was in the City, and we transferred at Mr Frothingham’s Office 27 shares of the Stock of the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States to John Lowell, and a new Certificate was made out to the Executors for 118 shares of the Stock, which was delivered to Mr Curtis— Mrs. Boylston came in a Carriage to the door of Mr Frothingham’s Office, where the book was taken down to her, and she signed her name in the carriage— I went next to the Registry of Probate, where were neither the judge, nor the register— I examined several volumes of the old Records for any thing to be found relating to John Quincy— I found his appointment of his Uncle Thomas Brattle as his Guardian datedSeptember 1708. in which he states himself to be in the 19th. year of his age— The Will of Mrs Anna Shepard, with the probate, which is not on the copy among the Mount Wollaston papers— An inventory of Mrs Shepard’s Estate, upon Oath, by Thomas Brattle as Guardian of John Quincy—and a Quit-claim, executed by John Quincy and Elizabeth his wife dated in 1719. to Mary Norton, widow and Administratrix of the Revd. John Norton, Minister of Hingham, Mrs Quincy’s Mother— I ordered copies of all these Papers. Then at the State House, I requested Mr Joseph B. Felt, to ascertain by the Records of the General Court, the years when John Quincy was a member of the House. The years when he was Speaker, and the years when he was a member of the Council— Also to ascertain the Record of a grant of Land to him be the General Court in 1735. and the traces of his services as a Commissioner for negotiating a Treaty with an Eastern tribe of Indians— All these facts Mr Felt promised to investigate, and to inform me of the result— At 1/2 past 12. an adjourned meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University in the Council chamber— Present only President Quincy, Dr John Pearce the Secretary, and Revd. Drs. Lamson, Frothingham, Francis Parkman, and Gray. I received a Letter from Mr John Pickering, a member of the Committee on the Doctorates, declaring his assent to the Report that they be all confirmed, John M’Lean, and Robert Grahame as Doctors of Laws F. W. P. Greenwood, Orville Dewey and George Rapall Noyes, Doctors of Divinity— I was Chairman of the Meeting of the board: made verbally the report of the Committee, and read the Letter received from Mr John Pickering— The report was adopted without opposition— President Quincy then presented the Resolutions of the Corporation proposing to repeal sundry parts of the By-Laws of the University, requiring Students returning from absence to report themselves to the College Freshman— I gave rise to some debate on these
these propositions, by enquiries, by what authority the College Freshman is appointed, and whether by releasing him from the performances of his duties the Office itself will be abolished— Finally the proposed repeal was confirmed, with a recommendation that the Office itself should be abolished— Other proposals of change in the Laws were presented— Particularly that after the Freshman year, the pursuit of Classical Studies of Greek and Latin should be made optional with the Students— Dr Frothingham objected to the consideration of measures so highly important at so thin a Meeting and moved its postponement to the annual meeting of the board next January, which was adopted— The Meeting was adjourned to next Wednesday Commencement Morning in the Library chamber at 9 O’Clock— I went home with Dr Frothingham, and while he went to his dinner with his friend Mr Stetson of Medford whom I found in his study I examined the Volume of the Records of the first Church, and found among the admissions to the Church, the following entry—3d. of the 1st. Month 1639. William Ting, Merchant—and among the baptisms 23d. day of the 3d. Month 1641. Bethiah, the daughter of our brother Mr William Ting, and 5th. day of 12th. Month 1642. Mercy the daughter of our brother Mr William Ting, being about 14 days old— I have thus ascertained the birth, and date of baptism of the four daughters of William Ting, who signed the Indenture of 28. March 1661— I found entries also of the admission to the Church of Mary, the wife of Edward Ting, and of the baptism of two of his daughters.— Farmer’s Register says that five daughters of William Ting are named in the Records—but I had not time to follow further the examination of the book— If there was a fifth daughter she must have died in childhood.— At 3. I walked from Dr Frothingham’s to Dr George Parkman’s, where I dined— The company, with Mrs Parkman, her Son and daughter were Mr R. G. Shaw, Dr Francis Parkman, Mr Shimmin, The Attorney General James T. Austin, a son of Dr Shattuck, Mr Samuel T. Armstrong and Mr Thomas Colley Grattan, just arrived as British Consul at Boston. There was a young man from Baltimore, and one or two others whose names I did not ascertain— Mr. Grattan is a nephew of the Irish Patriot Grattan of bygone days.— Mrs. Parkman mentioned that this Gentleman was the author certain recent popular works, called Highways and By Ways—and Sayings and Doings. He brought me a warm Letter of recommendation which he sent to me by the Mail. It was from Christopher Hughes in London— I enquired of him where he lodged— He said he was now at Nahant, but his City Quarters were at the Tremont— His manners are gentlemanly; but his face and form are the caricature of an ideal Irishman. I left the company about Sunset, and asked to speak a word with Mr Armstrong, who came away with me— I told him I intended to call upon Mr Blagden the Minister of the Old South Church, to request permission to examine the records of that Church, to ascertain if Daniel Quincy or his wife were members of that Church and if John Quincy was baptised there. Mr Armstrong said there was a printed list of all the members of the Old South Church, from the beginning which he would send me— Governor Everett was not at the Overseers Meeting—Mrs Everett having the day before yesterday broken her arm, by falling on the Stairs.
23. III:30. Friday.

The oppressive heat of the whole Summer has been concentrated upon this present week— This is the 4th. day upon which Fahrenheit has been at and over 90— For the first time this Season, I bathed and swam about 5 minutes at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, taking John Kirk with me. The bath was as pleasant to me, as it has been in former years, but a distrust of its subsequent operation upon the body was warranted by repeated experience of late years. A heavy drowsiness followed by profuse perspiration after my return—continuing till dinner time and for two hours after, disqualified me during that time for all intellectual exercise of reading, writing, or meditation— But towards the close of the afternoon I recovered spirit to write about an hour and a half— I went to Charles’s house to see the Sun set, but he was veiled in a thick cloud. His rise in the morning had also been intercepted by light vapours such as almost always cover the dawn of morning in the greatest summer heats. My Diary more that consumed the Day— Mr James Newcomb, one of the Assesors of the Parish Tax, brought my tax-bill, which I had left with him at the town Hall last Saturday— The particulars of the tax are now upon it— Homestead 2. Acres, Barn, orchard lot and farmhouse 5000 dollars— Penn’s Hill farm in part, viz 50 Acres wood, 7. Marsh an dwelling house with1/2 acre 3500. 190 acres woodland— 5500. Mount Wollaston Farm 22000. Real Estate in Boston and other parts of the Commonwealth 10,000. Personal Estate 74000— Sum total 120000 dollars; upon which an assessment of 17 1/2 cents to the 100 dollars has been laid— It makes a tax of 210 dollars for the year— Upon the Town and County tax Mr Newcomb told me the Assessment is 46 cents to the 100 dollars— He asked me some questions upon the construction of the Laws relating to the Assessment of taxes for the Schools, which I was not able to answer—the law is so ambiguous, respecting the Assessment on the Lands of non-residents that it is possible the term non-resident may refer either to the Town or to the School District— I thought the application was only to the Town, and that was the safer construction for the Assessors— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— My wife was unwell all the morning and kept her bed, till near time— I have at last turned to reading Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella— The two introductory Sections upon the previous history of Castile and of Arragon, before their Union by the marriage were so dry and uninteresting that before reading them through I became discouraged and had abandoned further reading of it altogether— But about a fortnight since, I took up the first volume again, and having waded through the two preliminary Sections, the moment I came to the personal history of Isabella, I found the interest highly excited, and now read from 25 to 40 pages of it every morning— There are many resemblances between the situation of Isabella in early life and that of Elizabeth of England— She was like Elizabeth the daughter of a second wife, and inherited the throne of Castile, after a half brother Henry 4th. and a brother, Alfonso, and in a competition with an ostensible daughter of Henry, Joanna Beltraneja— The Succession of Ferdinand to the crown of Arragon was alike precarious, and their marriage was accomplished against obstacles seemingly unsurmountable, has all the interest of a romance.
24. III:30. Saturday

Another blazing day, which disqualified me for labour— At Noon I went with Charles, and bathed and swam 5 minutes at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf. This ablution is still so grateful to me, that I relinquish it with extreme reluctance; but I feel that the nervous agitation consequent upon the bath for the remainder of the day and the subsequent night is much more trying than it was in former days— This afternoon after leaving with the Bookbinder Gill pamphlets to form a second Volume of my miscellaneous publications for my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, I called at the Town hall, and took my tax-bill, endorsing upon it the particulars, as they appear on the Assessment Book, which are Homestead House, 1/2 barn, Farm house, Orchard, 5100 dollars— Penn’s Hill farm in part, consisting of 50 Acres Wood, 7. Marsh, with one house and 1/2 Acre of Land, occupied by William Baxter, (now empty[)] 3500, 190 Acres of Woodland 6100. Personal Estate 75300—whole amount 90000 dollars upon which the Assessment of 46. cents to an Acre makes a tax of 414 dollars.—The Parish tax adds to this 22000 dollars for the Mount Wollaston farm, and 10000 dollars for real estate in other towns of the Commonwealth, but rates the personal estate at 75000 dollars the addition of 300 dollars in the town and County tax bill being made by the Assessors of the present year— The excessive charge is for personal Estate, of which the Assessors, Dr Duggan, and Mr James Newcomb could give no particulars, but said it had been at the same rate for many back years— I told them I should make up a Statement, to be presented to the Assessors for the next year, which would considerably reduce the charge upon my personal Estate— For the present, I should do no more— Returning home, I stop’d at Charles’s house and saw the Sun set from his porch at 6:49. Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— And Mr Lunt who returned several books that he had borrowed— I received a Letter from Mr Joseph B. Felt containing statements from the Records of the Province, relating to the life of
John Quincy—

list.item: First appeared as Representative in the General Court. 29. May 1717.

Served in the same capacity from 27. May 1719. to 29. May 1741.— from 30. May 1744 to 28 May 1746 also recorded among the deputies 27. May 1747. and then chosen a Member of the Council— He had been first elected a member of the Council in 26. May 1742 and in the latter part of the year 1746 and till May 1747. and from thence annually till 30. May 1754.— He was Speaker from 28. May 1729. to 30 May 1739. when Paul Dudley was chosen Speaker, but being negatived by the Governor John Quincy was again chosen— In part of that year and of 1740. he was absent from the House and Ebenezer Pomroy was Speaker pro Tem—

53: 1716 to be paid to John Quincy Esqr and Mr Edward White as a Committee for reviewing the forces. 15. Decr. 1722.— Appointed Trustee for the Puncapaug Indians. 30. Decr. 1726—and continued their guardian, till 22. Feby 1748. when he resigned

500 Acres of unappropriated Province lands granted to him by the general Court for his constant application in giving dispatch to the public affairs of the Province for divers year’s last past 2. January 1736.

div.p: 25. IV. Sunday.

Heard Mr Francis of Watertown, this morning from Acts 17:31. [“]Because he hath appointed a day, in the which he will judge the world in righteousness, by that man whom he hath ordained.” This is a part of that ever memorable discourse of Paul at Athens. The light in which it was considered by Mr Francis was original and ingenious—perhaps somewhat refined. An appointed day of judgment, by a man ordained to judge— A man to judge the world in righteousness!— Mr Francis did not include in his text, the remainder of the verse—“whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead.” Here is the distinct assertion, that god hath appointed a day in which he will judge the world in righteousness by the man Christ Jesus— And as a demonstration of this to all mankind, he, God, had raised that man from the dead— Is it not amazing that after language so distinct and explicit as this, nine tenths of the Christian world believe that this man, whom God raised from the dead to prove that he should be the judge of the world, was himself almighty God? and how can he who believes this, scruple to believe that a wafer mystified by the incantation of a Priest is turned into God almighty, and then swallowed by the communicant? Of all this Mr Francis took no account—but the improvement of his discourse was that the Christian, who will one day be judged in righteousness should so live as to consider every day of his life a day of judgment. Mr Francis dined with us, and his afternoon text was from Acts 21:11. “And when he was come unto us he took Paul’s Girdle, and bound his own hands and feet, and said, thus saith the holy Ghost, So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man that owneth this girdle”—the verse adds, and shall deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles; but Mr Francis left these words out of his text— The discourse was upon the language of action. It was the first Sermon upon this subject that I had ever heard, and I have often wondered how it happened that the discussion of the figurative language of the Scriptures has been so little attended to by the writers of Sermons— Mr Francis began by the very obvious remark that action was a vehicle of thought and of feeling as effective as speech— He referred to the frequent employment of this mode of communication, by the prophets of the old Testament, and to the use of it by Jesus Christ in the new. He spoke of it as an Oriental usage; but it belongs to the nature of man— Demosthenes said that all eloquence consisted in action—action—action—and Speech itself is but a modification of action— And this is a key to the intelligence of the Scriptures the ignorance or neglect of which has caused more absurd and senseless doctrines to be wrought up into creeds and to kindle the fires of persecution, than all the other blunders of the human imagination put together— Mr Francis noticed particularly the emphatic act of Jesus to rebuke the ambition and thirst for place of his disciples, by taking and placing a little child in the midst of them— After Meeting I read Dr Parker’s 5th. Sermon— A childlike disposition essential to the Christian character—a Sermon altogether congenial to that which I had just heard from Mr Francis— I read also two or three chapters of Basnage’s history of the Jews, with little satisfaction— He begins with the Herods— Sunset at Charles porch; beclouded— Mrs John Angier and Elizabeth C. Adams were here, with a young lad from St Iago de Cuba, and with Francis De Wint, five years of age. His father and mother are at Boston.
26. III:30. Monday
Sun rose 5:18.— Set 6:46. day 13 hours 28 minutes.

Mrs. Angier was here this morning and again this afternoon when she returned to Medford— She took a sketch of our dwelling house, and borrowed that which Miss Eliza Susan Quincy gave me some years since— She asked me also for my signature for a friend of hers a collector of Autographs; and I added to the signature a Sonnet to a Sun dial, which I wrote some years ago; and which no reader but my self ever thought good for any thing; and which I think good for much.— Dr Phelps of Boston paid me an afternoon visit with his Son, a young man at the Schenectady College, now in vacation—pale, slender and ghostly, his father said from too intense study— He seems to be an intelligent youth. I asked Dr Phelps what had become of Anti-Masonry— He said it had accomplished its destiny. Masonry was extinguished in this Commonwealth except for the management of its property— And he had thought when Masonry was extinct there was no longer any necessity for keeping up an antimasonic party. I asked him how he stood about the democracy and the 15 gallon law— He said he took no interest in them; nor any part in Politics— The Doctor was one of the most ardent, and I believe most consciencious Anti-Masons.— He gave me an urgent invitation to visit him in his present residence N. 23. Oliver Street.— Mrs Edmund Quincy with her little Son Edmund and Miss Anna Quincy visit our Ladies— I bathed with Charles, at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf and swam five minutes; and after dinner took a ride with him to Mount Wollaston and to Germantown.— In the Evening I walked to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s to see his Son E. Price, who is just recovering from a most alarming and dangerous inflammation and swelling of the root of the tongue which for three or four days closed almost entirely the passage of the throat; deprived him of the power of Speech, and awfully protruded the tongue out of the Mouth— Relieved only by copious bleeding both of the lancet and by leaches— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— I answered an invitation from the Directors of the Philadelphia mercantile Library Association to deliver a Lecture before that Association next November, which I declined— My principal exercise is, labouring in observation upon my seedling plants, which I follow up without intermission almost every day— We had yesterday at dinner the first ripe early ann peaches which are small but very good— A third walnut has come up thus late in the border near the kitchen garden gate where I have 17. Ash seedlings 8 button woods self planted 4 peachesApples and Pears, all of the present year, and shewing every variety of growth from 2 feet to 2 inches— This day, the plumelet of the Apple seedling nearest the seminary gate which had been steadily shooting up since the first of May, was eroded by some caterpillar or bug, and its growth for the remainder of this Season is arrested— Its taller neighbour whose leading shoots started only about a month since, continues to grow— The shoots from two of the three stunted which had started make no progress
27. IV. Tuesday.

I went to Boston this morning with Charles, and stopped at Dr Frothingham’s house. He was not at home, but as I had been invited by him I went into his study, and resumed the examination of the volume of records of the first Church— I found no further notices of William Ting, or of his children; but the following entries of baptisms

row.cell: daughter of our brother Mr Edward Ting
daughters of our brother John Hull
daughter of our Sister Hannah Hull
the Son of Mr Thomas Brattle

div.p: But no name of Daniel Quincy, his wife or either of his children could I find. Dr Frothingham came while I was engaged with the book, which took upwards of two hours— I then went to Mr Blagden’s the Minister of the old South Church to examine his book, but he was out of town. I attended the Meeting of the Historical Society at Noon, and presented to the Society

row.cell: Letters to W. L. Stone on the entered Apprentices Oath
Letters on Masonry to Edward Livingston
Speech (suppressed) on the removal of the Deposits
Proceedings of the Overseers of Harvard University
Speech on the right of Petition &c.

div.p:
These are of my own composition—and I also presented the pamphlet called the War in Texas— The Address of Revd. Charles Brooks 4. July 1837 and that of Revd W. P. Lunt in 1738 at Quincy—and the English pamphlet called Negro Apprenticeship in the British Colonies.— Some other donations were received— Mr Thomas L Winthrop the President, proposed for an honorary member of the Society Mr Waldek who has written upon the ruined cities of Copan and Palenque in central America, and he shewed me a Letter to him dated last March from Mr Galindo, on the same subject— Mr F. C. Gray reported from a Committee to engage Lecturers for next Winter that they propose to have one a week—twelve in number
number, and they intended to propose; that the future annual volumes of the Society should be published by subscription— I mentioned the paper in the 10th Volume of the Society’s publications—page 180. by Timothy Alden junr. in which it is asserted that the first William Ting passed his life at Braintree, and left no posterity— I observed that this statement was incorrect, and that I intended to address a Letter to the President to rectify the error— And I said if there was any of the members present who had particular knowledge of the families of Ting, or Shepard or Brattle, I should be grateful for the communication of it— Judge Nahum Mitchell was present and spoke of a person named John Quincy Keith, baptized at Bridgewater in 1769.— He said also that John Holman removed from Milton to Bridgewater and died there leaving a family and that Abigail Baxter, wife of the first Joseph Adams was a daughter of Gregory Baxter. The Meeting adjourned just after 1. and Isaac P Davis went with me to the Common Council chamber in the Old State-House— There upon examining the city records, I found entries of the birth of Anna daughter of Daniel and Anna Quinsie 1 June 1685—and of John son of the same 21 July 1689— I had no time for further examination and came home with Charles—to dine— After dinner Mr Thomas Loring, and Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter were here— Miss Thaxter invited our Ladies to a tea party next Friday, and Mr Loring invited me to a fishing party the same day to which I promised to go, if the weather should be fair and cool.— This day was the roaster of the Season— Charles and his wife passed the evening here.
28 III:30 Wednesday.
Sun rose beclouded 5.20 Set clear 6.42

A Mr Arnold from Braintree came and informed me that the County Commissioners were to meet this afternoon for a final determination upon a Petition to open a road from Braintree through at least 200 rods of my land— The Commissioners had already decided to lay out the road, if the cost of it should not exceed 500 dollars, and this would probably depend upon the amount of damages that I should claim and obtain— He intimated a wish that I should attend or send some person for me to attend the Meeting— I told him that every road laid out through my lands was an injury to my property— That the Commissioners never allowed me damages adequate to the injury That I did not wish to interpose my private interest against any road which would be useful and desirable to the people of Quincy or of Braintree and therefore I should let the County Commissioners decide as they think proper, and if they did not allow me adequate damages I must put up with the loss. Mr Minott Thayer was here with a Son of Mr Thomas Phillips of Boston. Mr Thayers object was to ask me to fix a day upon which I am to preach to the people of Braintree, for the passion for hearing Lectures, Addresses, Orations and the like has taken hold of this people with such fury that if it continues we shall soon become a Nation of Preachers— I told Mr Thayer I could not yet fix upon a day, nor yet tell him the subject upon which I should discourse; for that I had a great aversion to that of education hacknied as it was, and upon which it is impossible for me to say anything new— He said the
people would attend more to what I should say, than if it should be said by any one else; which is all fudge— I told him that as soon as I could possibly fix the day, I would let him know— Mrs Tarbell and Miss Susan Tufts were here this afternoon— I saw the sun set perfectly clear from Charles’s porch— He and his wife and children dined with us— The heat of the Sun was not so intense as yesterday— I had not despatched my answer to the Committee of Directors of the Mercantile Library Company at Philadelphia, declining to deliver a Lecture before them next November, before I received a second Letter from them reiterating the application— I answered this day also a Letter from Ira M Barton, in behalf of the Directors of the Worcester Lyceum, inviting me to deliver the introductory Lecture to their course next October which I declined, and a second Letter from Shenard Clemens, Silas Condit and Charles S. M’Colloh, to inform me of my election as an honorary member of the Union Literary Society of Washington College Pennsylvania, which honour I accept.— Invitations to deliver Addresses, Lectures and Orations—Autographs—Verses for Album’s, and elections as an honorary member of Literary Societies constitute four fifths of my present correspondence, and are annoying more than mosquitos or gad-flies. It seems as if nothing could be done in this Country, but by association— This was Commencement day at Harvard University.
29. III:15. Thursday

I left home this morning as the Clock struck seven with Charles’s four wheeled Chaise: one of our horses and Thomas Dumphy to drive, and at half past 8 alighted at Cambridge— I was first at the President’s Study— There came in afterwards Messrs C. P CurtisLowell, P. Sprague, Walkis, and T. W. Ward—and two others— At 9 we proceeded to the Meeting-house— There were 21 competitors for the prizes—6. from the Junior, 12 from the senior and 3 from the class yesterday graduated. The declamations lasted nearly 3 hours. One of the juniors and three of the Senior class did not perform— After the speaking had closed the judges returned to the President’s study and awarded the two first prizes to Robert Henry Harlow of the junior Class who delivered part of a Speech of Charles Phillips on America and to John Chandler Bancroft Davis a Senior, son of the Senator John Davis, who spoke part of a Speech of Sir Charles Wetherell in the House of Commons on reform in Parliament. The three second prizes were awarded to Henry Frederick Bond, Thomas Worthington King, a Son of the late Edward King, both of the Senior and Wickham Hoffman of the junior class— The graduates took no one of the prizes— Immediately after the declaration of the prizes, I went over and joined the procession of the members of the Φ.Β.Κ. Society which was forming at HHall according to the graduation of classes commencing with that of the present year— When they got back to 1787. I was the solitary member but of the Class before me there were three—Dr. John Andrews, Alden Βradford and Samuel P. Gardner. I walked with them— The Orator was Caleb Cushing, the member of Congress— The Poet Revd. Dr James Flynt of Salem— The service commenced by a very excellent prayer from RevdStearns. Mr Cushing’s Oration occupied
nearly two hours in the delivery, and was an ingenious elaborate and eloquent discussion of some of the prevailing projects of political reform—of the claim of political rights of women—of perpetual Peace by the means of a Congress of Nations—Non-resistance and no Government the ones all of which he subjected to analysis, to logical scrutiny and to searching sarcasm the composition of the discourse was rather negligent, aiming rather at the tone of unpremeditated conversation than at the studied organization of periods in the closet. He spoke not from the pulpit but before a table and a slanting desk on the stage, as I did at New-York— Dr Flynt did the same— His poem took about half an hour upon the perpetual change incident to this world. A sort of Canto of Mutability— It was in the syllable couplet versification generally good, with here and there a quibble a quillet and a pun—food for a moderate and momentary laugh: with a tribute warm from the heart in honour of the former president Joseph Willard— Judge Story, the President of the Society urged me warmly to go and dine with them; but I was engaged to dine with President Quincy—Mrs Quincy—their Son Edmund their daughters Mrs Green with her husband, Eliza Susan, and Sophia—Professor Adam, F. C. Gray, Mr John Amory Lowell, Ellis Gray Loring, Mr Daniel P. Parker father of Mrs Edmund Quincy—Revd. Mr Pierpont—Mr Peleg Sprague, Dr Palfrey, Professor Walker, and T. W. Ward the Treasurer of the College formed the company— After dinner, Mr Cushing, Mr Josiah Quincy junr. and MrEmerson came in from the Φ.Β.Κ. dinner which they said had been eminently jovial, and where among the festivities, professor Henry Ware junr. had produced a poem on the authors of the Society. Mrs Quincy gave me to bring home a basket of grapes, peaches, plumbs, and a Nectarine from the Cushing and Perkins Hot houses— It was near 7. when I left Cambridge, and past 8 when I reached home safe having rode about half the way in the dark— Mr Grattan the British Consul was at the Φ.B.K. performances and at the dinner— Some one told me, but I cannot recollect who, that at the Φ.B.K. anniversary of Yale College last week I was elected to deliv the anniversary oration of the next year— Another temptation.— At the Commencement yesterday, sixty one youths were graduated bachelors of Arts. Thirty one of whom had parts to perform— President Quincy told me that the performances were satisfactory, and the speaking better than usual— One only of the graduates of yesterday had a part and declaimed this day for a prize. His name is John Kebler of Roxbury: but he is by birth a German, and speaks with something of a German accent. He is quite distinguished as a scholar, and spoke so well that he would have taken a prize; but that he made two or three long aukward pauses from a failure of memory— No prompting is allowed, and by the rule, no prize can be taken in any case of failure of memory.
30. III:30. Friday

I had engaged if the weather should be this day fair, to go to Hingham for a fishing party with Mr Loring, and the Ladies had engaged for a tea-party at Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter’s; but we were all confined to the house by a violent North-eastern gale and storm, which had been two days gathering and came on so gradually this morning, that Charles with whom I had promised to go, came to enquire what I had concluded to do— The gale had been heavy in the Night without rain— A clear streak of sky along the eastern horizon, with dark super impending clouds over the whole hemisphere besides, portended a stormy day. It was no time to go upon salt water to take fish— Charles nevertheless went into Boston, and returned to dine.— There were light sprinklings of rain all the morning, not amounting to a shower, and not sufficient to lay the dust till about 2. P.M. when a steady driving rain set in which continued without abatement of the gale, and the torrent and the blast still continued when about ten at night, I betook myself to my rest— We had a fire in the dining room from noon, and I felt the want of one in my library but did not indulge myself with it.

I finished reading the first volume of W. H. Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella, which I have read with great delight— The introductory Sections had almost discouraged me by their dulness; yet they were necessary to the plan of the work, which is exceedingly well formed; and from the moment he comes to the birth of Isabella 22. April 1451 at Madrigal, all is liveliness and Spirit— One of the most remarkable phenomena in the natural history of man is the production of such a person as Isabella— Her father was indeed the son of Catherine of Lancaster daughter of John of Gaunt and from that line something might come; but from such a birth, such an education, and such family co-temporaries, she seems like a diamond glancing to the Sun in the midst of a Sandy desart— The work is divided into two parts— The first narrating the marriage of Ferdinand and Isabella, with the Event, leading to it, and the reforms introduced upon the Union of the Crowns of Arragon and of Castile— The Domestic policy including the conquest of Granada— The rise, fall, and character of Alvaro de Luna— The Literary qualities and political adventures of the marquis of Villena, and of Inigo Lopez de Mendoza, Marquis of Santillana, father of the first Duke de L’Infantado— The poetic fame of John de Mena, and the Cancionero of Alfonso de Baena the converted Jew, strew the historian’s path with flowers— The story of Ferdinand, born at Sos in Arragon on 10 March 1452—is far less pleasing—his claims and his fortune having originated in the intrigues and perhaps the crime of his mother by which he supplanted his half brother Carlos, the son of a former marriage and 32 years older than him— The War for the Castilian succession against the putative half-sister niece of Isabella, Joanna Beltraneja and the internal administration of Castille, after the accession of the conjugal authority, are deeply interesting; and the melancholy tale of the establishment of the modern inquisition, while it detracts from the estimation we have formed of the almost spotless character of Isabella leads us but to lament the bigotry of the age which could enchain and subdue so pure and so exalted, and to acquit her if possible of all individual blame. The War for the Conquest of Granada continues in the narrative of the second volume.
31. V. Saturday

The storm raved through the night, and rivetted me to my Couch till 5. O’Clock this morning— When I rose the rain was still rattling at my Northern and Eastern windows, and the gale was driving with unabated fury: after Sunrise however the torrent first subsided and the tempest gradually lulled—the clouds slowly dispersed— By Noon the Sun peered out for a few minutes and veiled himself again, with clouds— Alternations of shade and Sunshine succeeded till the setting of the orb of day in a clear sky— But the storm had left the wreck of many a fruit-tree snapped off in the midst—uprooted hundreds of hills of unripened Indian corn, and scattered bushels upon bushels of green Apples, Pears Peaches and Plums upon the ground. The damage done is great and irreparable for the present year— I made the rounds of my garden, nursery, Orchard and Seminary, to witness the desolation of my trees, and the ruin of many of my hopes— I began reading the second Volume of Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella; after dinner walked to the Bookbinder Gill’s, and left the Reports on the Commerce and Navigation of the United States for the last 8 years to be bound in two Volumes— Returning home I stopped at Charles’s house, and while I was there Mr Ebenezer Adams came, and delivered to me a Letter from Mr Nathaniel Curtis requesting me to furnish by Monday Morning for Mr Fuller the draught of a Petition which I had promised from the children of the late Moses Gill to the judge of Probate for the County of Worcester to grant Letters of Administration upon the Estates of Governor Gill, and of the late Moses Gill to Mr Fuller, for the settlement of the Gill claim on the sum recovered from the French Government, and from Petty Vaughan in the right of Thomas Boylston— I came home immediately and made a draught of the Petition— After dark two young Ladies brought me a note from the Ladies of Quincy inviting my wife and me to a Pic-Nic party at the Hancock lot, next Wednesday at 3. O’Clock PM— In the Evening we had visits from Mr Edmund Quincy and a Mr Manford, heretofore a resident of Baltimore and now of Philadelphia— Charles and his wife were here— Miss Samson, the Seamstress from Braintree has been here the whole of this week and went home this Evening.

Day— I rise between 3 and 5 O’Clock—upon the average about 4. In the fair warm weather, after taking a full half hour to wash and dress I water my potted seedling plants, dig round the trees go up the Hill to see the Sunrise— Then return to my chamber, read a chapter or two in the History of Ferdinand and Isabella; and write half a page or less in this diary— Breakfast about 8. Hear my granddaughters Mary-Louisa and Georgiana Frances read 5 chapters in the Bible before or after breakfast— Receive the mail—Letters, Newspapers, Pamphlets—three hours of waste reading— Dine between 2 and 3. Siesta— Write an hour or two. Evening till 10. P.M. with my family— Nothing done.
